title: 112_s3214
content: The "Today's Entrepreneurs are America's Mentors Act" or the "TEAM Act" defines terms like "Administration" and "small business concern" as per the Small Business Act. It also establishes the Office of Entrepreneurial Education. The Small Business Act is amended to include a new section on Entrepreneurial Education, establishing the Office of Entrepreneurial Education. The Small Business Act is amended to establish the Office of Entrepreneurial Education within the Administration. This office will provide innovative entrepreneurial information, education, and resources to support prospective entrepreneurs and successful small businesses. The Director of the Office reports to the Associate Administrator for Entrepreneurial Development and is responsible for developing and delivering these services. The Office of Entrepreneurial Education manages online courses, publications, and resources for entrepreneurs and small businesses. It also oversees youth entrepreneurship programs, including online resources and coordination with service providers. The Office of Entrepreneurial Education coordinates with service providers to offer counseling and training for youth entrepreneurs. They also collaborate with private sector partners to share financial literacy materials and provide assistance to small business concerns. The Office of Entrepreneurial Education offers counseling, training, and financial literacy for youth entrepreneurs and small business concerns. They also provide assistance to individuals and foreign dignitaries interested in these issues. Additionally, there is a National Primary and Secondary School Entrepreneurial Education Program established under the Today's Entrepreneurs are America's Mentors Act. The Associate Administrator for Entrepreneurial Development will establish a program to provide grants to nonprofit organizations for technical assistance in promoting entrepreneurship in primary and secondary schools. The Associate Administrator for Entrepreneurial Development will provide grants to nonprofit organizations for implementing curricula and mentoring programs to promote entrepreneurship. Nonprofit organizations must submit an application outlining project goals, partners involved, and any other required information. Nonprofit organizations receiving grants must submit a report within 1 year detailing the individuals assisted, jobs created or saved, and any other required information as determined by the Associate Administrator. The Director of the Office of Entrepreneurial Education must submit a report on best practices of entrepreneurial education and training programs to the Committee on Small Business and Entrepreneurship within 180 days of the enactment of the Act. Authorization of $3,000,000 for fiscal years 2013, 2014, and 2015 is provided for this purpose. Entrepreneurial Education will report best practices of entrepreneurial education and training programs to Senate and House committees. This includes exemplary national, regional, state, and local programs. The report will include details on entrepreneurial education and training programs at the national, regional, state, and local levels, as well as programs conducted by the Federal Government, State and local governments, nonprofit organizations, and private sector groups. SEC. 4. MASTER OF BUSINESS ADMINISTRATION SCHOLARSHIP PILOT PROGRAM. The Administrator may award up to 100 scholarships of $1,500 each to MBA students on a competitive basis. Recipients must provide free assistance to small businesses for 1-2 weeks. The Administrator awards scholarships to MBA students for providing assistance to small businesses for 1-2 weeks. Requirements ensure at least 50% of recipients are students at institutions with limited entrepreneurship opportunities. Activities support various small businesses. The activities under agreements support small business concerns and entrepreneurial projects, including investigator-led, interdisciplinary, and multi-institutional projects. Each student receiving a scholarship has a mentor to help relate their academic study to the assistance provided. The student receiving a scholarship must provide information on the use of assistance and employment status for 3 years after graduation. Failure to comply results in consequences. If a student fails to comply with the agreement for a scholarship, the amount received will be treated as a loan and must be repaid with interest according to specified terms. The Administrator is authorized to award scholarships with specified terms and conditions. $200,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2013 to 2015. Scholarships cannot be awarded after September 30, 2015. SEC. 5. REGIONAL ENTREPRENEURIAL COMPETITIONS. The Administrator will establish a program for regional competitions and a national conference to address challenges through entrepreneurial research and business planning. Regional offices will identify issues and sponsor competitions among small businesses and inventors. The program will sponsor regional competitions for small businesses, inventors, and entrepreneurs to submit research and business plans. Outreach will be provided to universities, colleges, business communities, industry leaders, and nonprofit organizations to promote the competition and request proposals. The program will sponsor regional competitions for small businesses, inventors, and entrepreneurs to submit research and business plans. The Administrator will select the top 3 plans addressing the identified issue and submit a report to the Administrator. The Administrator will also organize a conference through the Associate Administrator for Field Operations. The Administrator will organize a national conference for selected research and business plans presented by regional administrators. A panel of 11 employees will be designated to select the plans. The Administrator will organize a national conference for selected research and business plans presented by regional administrators. A panel of 11 employees will be designated to select the best plan from each region addressing the identified issue. The Administrator will award a $50,000 grant to individuals or groups with selected plans. Recipients must submit a report on grant usage within a year. The Administrator authorizes $750,000 for grants under this section, with recipients required to submit a report on grant usage. The Administrator, in consultation with the Secretary of Education, must submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The report will include recommendations for legislation to forgive student loans and defer repayments to support youth entrepreneurship by providing capital for business formation.
